ground_truth: He fetches a liquor bottle from beneath the rocking chair; about to pour he does a take at Bess's photograph. It stands in a cabinet frame: a fine-looking young woman in archaic dress, with sharp, accusing black eyes. He turns the picture away and splashes liquor into his coffee. They drink. John looks cautious. Birdie's face falls; he takes another drink. John puts his cup down and gets up. He heads for the door. John runs up the bank, not looking back. He runs up the street close to Spoon's and stops dead. He is horrified by what he sees. Group shot through door-glass, from John's viewpoint Preacher, Willa, and Pearl surround a little table. Walt stands by, puffing his pipe. Icey in the background, stirs fudge at a little soda-fountain stove. Willa looks both moved and pleased. Pearl, shyly flirting with Preacher, all but hides in Willa's skirts. Preacher dandles Pearl's doll on his knee as he talks. All the grownups are avid for his words, which we don't hear through the glass. We shoot through the door; he quietly enters. They look casually to John and continue talking. Over this John enters the shot and stands at the fringe of the group, staring at Preacher's hands and at the doll. He hands the doll to Pearl. John's eyes follow the doll. Preacher holds up both hands to John. John looks back at his hands. John stands still. They are impressed in their different ways. Slight applause from the adults. Preacher takes Pearl, with her doll, onto his lap. He does a little take. His eyes twinkle palely. Something new enters his eyes; a game has begun between them. A tight silence. Icey pours fudge into a buttered pan. Few men in proportion to women and children. We center Preacher. The women watch him and admire him. He gives Willa the eye as we pan to center Willa, who looks wooed and self-conscious. Icey enters the shot and whispers and beckons Willa and, as the singing continues, they leave the group and start towards a shade tree in medium ground, which we pan to center. They walk; singers in background. Willa nods. Icey, looking ahead, is displeased. They sit on the bench, their backs to us, partly concealed by the tree trunk. They look around. Icey and Willa enter the shot, their backs to us. They sit on the bench, their back to us. The children recede towards the river in background. Willa meekly keeps her head down. Singing continues o.s. Icey pivots and we pan over her to children by river. John looks up from pebble-skimming and loosens his tie. His brow is furrowed. He skims another pebble.

It stands in a cabinet frame: a handsome young woman in old-fashioned attire, with piercing, accusing black eyes. He turns the picture away and sloshes spirits into his coffee. They sip. John looks wary. Birdie's countenance falls; he takes another sip. John places his cup down and rises. He heads for the exit. John runs up the embankment, not looking back. He sprints up the avenue close to Spoon's and stops abruptly. He is appalled by what he observes. Group shot through door-glass, from John's perspective Preacher, Willa, and Pearl encircle a little table. Walt stands by, puffing his pipe. Slight applause from the adults. Preacher takes Pearl, with her figurine, onto his lap. He does a little glance. His eyes twinkle faintly. Something new enters his eyes; a game has commenced between them. A tight silence. Icey pours fudge into a buttered pan. Few men in proportion to women and children. We center Preacher. The women observe him and admire him. He gives Willa the eye as we pan to center Willa, who looks wooed and self-conscious. Icey enters the shot and whispers and beckons Willa and, as the singing continues, they leave the group and start towards a shade tree in medium ground, which we pan to center. Icey and Willa enter the shot, their backs to us. They sit on the bench, their backs to us. The children recede towards the river in the background. Willa meekly keeps her head down. test_cases.name: Brevity - L1
test_cases.description: He retrieves a liquor bottle from beneath the rocking chair and pauses, glancing at Bess's photo. It's in a cabinet frame: a young woman in old-fashioned dress with sharp black eyes. He turns the picture away, pours liquor into his coffee, and they drink. John looks wary, while Birdie's expression drops, taking another sip. John places his cup down, stands, and heads to the door. He runs up the bank, not looking back, and stops abruptly near Spoon's, horrified by what he sees. Through the door-glass, John's view reveals Preacher, Willa, and Pearl at a table, with Walt smoking a pipe nearby. Icey, in the background, stirs fudge at a soda-fountain stove. Willa appears moved and happy, while Pearl shyly hides behind her, flirting with Preacher, who bounces Pearl's doll on his knee. Adults eagerly listen to him, though his words are inaudible through the glass. John enters quietly, standing at the group's edge, observing Preacher's hands and the doll. Preacher hands the doll to Pearl, and John's gaze follows it. Preacher gestures to John with both hands, who remains still, impressing the adults. Slight applause follows, and Preacher seats Pearl and her doll on his lap, his eyes twinkling as a new game begins. A tight silence ensues while Icey pours fudge into a pan. Few men are present compared to women and children. The focus is on Preacher, admired by the women, who exchange glances with Willa. As we pan to Willa, Icey approaches, whispers to her, and they leave the group, heading towards a shaded bench, singers providing background music. Willa nods meekly while Icey remains displeased. They sit on the bench, backs to us, partly hidden by the tree. The children recede towards the river, singing continues off screen. Icey pivots, and we pan to children by the river. John's brow is furrowed as he looks up from pebble-skimming and loosens his tie, then skims another pebble.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L2
test_cases.description: He retrieves a liquor bottle from under the rocking chair, glancing at Bess's photograph—an attractive woman in old-fashioned attire with piercing eyes. He turns it aside, pours liquor into his coffee, and they drink. John is cautious; Birdie looks downcast and drinks again. John leaves, running up the street until he stops in shock. Through door-glass, he sees Preacher, Willa, and Pearl at a table, Walt with his pipe, and Icey making fudge. Willa appears pleased, while Pearl shyly interacts with Preacher, who entertains her doll. Everyone listens intently. John enters, observing Preacher's hands and the doll. Preacher gestures, and John watches, standing still. The group is silently impressed. Preacher takes Pearl on his lap; a silent game begins. Icey pours fudge, with more women and children present. Focus on Preacher, admired by Willa. Icey signals Willa, and they move to a tree, sitting with backs to us. Children head towards the river, singing continues off-screen. Icey turns, directing attention to children by the river. John frowns while skimming pebbles and loosens his tie.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L1
test_cases.description: He carefully retrieves a liquor bottle from its hidden spot beneath the old rocking chair. Just as he is about to pour himself a drink, he pauses for a moment and glances at a photograph of Bess. The photograph is displayed in an elegant cabinet frame, capturing a fine-looking young woman in an archaic style of dress, her sharp black eyes projecting an accusatory gaze. He decides to turn the picture away and proceeds to splash some liquor into his coffee. Both of them drink in silence. John appears to be cautious and contemplative. Birdie's expression changes, a sense of disappointment washing over his face as he takes another sip. John places his cup down with deliberation and gets up from his seat. He makes his way towards the door, exiting the room. John runs swiftly up the bank, making a deliberate decision not to look back. He continues running up the street until he is close to Spoon's, where he abruptly stops, frozen in place and utterly horrified by the sight before him. Through the glass of the door, from John's perspective, a group scene unfolds. Preacher, Willa, and Pearl are gathered around a small table, while Walt stands nearby, leisurely puffing on his pipe. In the background, Icey is busy stirring fudge at a little soda-fountain stove. Willa appears both touched and pleased, while Pearl, shyly interacting with Preacher, almost hides within the folds of Willa’s skirts. Preacher gently balances Pearl's doll on his knee as he speaks. Although his words remain unheard through the glass, all the adults are intensely focused and eager for what he has to say. As the scene unfolds, we move through the door into the room; John quietly enters the space. They glance at John briefly, then continue their conversation as if he were part of the furniture. As this unfolds, John steps into the shot and stands on the fringes of the group, his gaze fixed on Preacher's hands and the doll. Preacher passes the doll back to Pearl, and John’s eyes track its movement. Preacher then raises both hands toward John, who looks down at his own hands in response. John stands still, unmoving. Each adult in the room is impressed in their own distinct way, and there is a subtle round of applause from them. Preacher takes Pearl, still clutching her doll, onto his lap, and executes a slight double take. His eyes glimmer with a pale twinkle, as if a game has commenced between them. An uneasy silence descends over the room. Icey carefully pours the hot fudge into a buttered pan, drawing our attention to the noticeable imbalance of men to women and children present. Our focus returns to Preacher, who is at the center of attention. The women observe him with admiration. He exchanges a meaningful look with Willa as we shift our focus to her, capturing Willa looking both flattered and self-conscious. Icey enters the scene, whispering something to Willa before beckoning her. As the singing continues in the background, they both leave the group and start walking towards a shady tree located in the middle ground, which we move to center in our view. As they walk away, with the singers still heard faintly in the background, Willa nods in acknowledgment. Icey, looking ahead, shows signs of disapproval. They sit on a bench with their backs turned to us, partially concealed by the trunk of the tree. They both glance around cautiously. As Icey and Willa enter the shot again, their backs are once more to us as they sit on the bench. In the background, the children gradually move towards the river. Willa keeps her head meekly bowed. The singing continues softly, off-screen. Icey pivots, and we pan over to capture the children by the river. John glances up from his pebble-skimming activity and loosens his tie, his brow etched with a thoughtful furrow. He skillfully skims another pebble across the water's surface.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L2
test_cases.description:
He meticulously retrieves a liquor bottle from its well-concealed spot hidden beneath the aging, creaking rocking chair. Just as he is about to pour himself a drink, he hesitates for a brief moment and allows his gaze to wander to a photograph of Bess. This photograph, elegantly displayed within a sophisticated cabinet frame, depicts a fine-looking young woman dressed in an archaic style, her sharp black eyes projecting an accusatory gaze that seems to pierce through time. He makes the decision to turn the picture away and proceeds to casually splash some liquor into his coffee. They both continue to drink in silence, a palpable tension hanging in the air. John appears to be cautious and contemplative, deep in thought. Birdie's expression shifts noticeably, with a sense of disappointment washing over his features as he takes another sip from his cup. John places his cup down with careful deliberation before getting up from his seat with measured intent. He makes his way toward the door, exiting the room with unspoken resolve. 

John runs swiftly up the bank, consciously choosing not to glance back. He continues running up the street, his pace not slowing, until he is close to Spoon's, where he comes to an abrupt halt, frozen in place and utterly horrified by the scene unfolding before him. Through the glass of the door, from John's perspective, a group scene reveals itself. Preacher, Willa, and Pearl are gathered around a small table, while Walt stands nearby, leisurely puffing on his pipe with an air of relaxed detachment. In the background, Icey is busily engaged in the act of stirring fudge at a little soda-fountain stove. Willa appears to be both touched and pleased, while Pearl, shyly interacting with Preacher, almost conceals herself within the protective folds of Willa’s skirts. Preacher gently balances Pearl's doll on his knee as he speaks, his words remaining unheard through the glass, yet all the adults are intensely focused and eager to hear what he has to say. 

As the scene continues to unfold before them, we move through the door into the room; John quietly enters the space, his presence acknowledged only briefly by the others before they resume their conversation, treating him as if he were part of the furniture. As this scene progresses, John steps into the shot and stands on the fringes of the group, his attention fixed on Preacher's hands and the doll. Preacher passes the doll back to Pearl, and John’s eyes carefully track its movement with intent observation. Preacher then raises both hands toward John, who instinctively looks down at his own hands in response. John remains standing still, unmoving. Each adult in the room seems impressed in their own distinct way, prompting a subtle round of applause from them. Preacher takes Pearl, still clutching her doll, onto his lap, and executes a slight double take. His eyes glimmer with a pale twinkle, as if a game has commenced between them, casting an atmosphere of mystery and intrigue. An uneasy silence descends over the room. Icey carefully pours the hot fudge into a buttered pan, drawing our attention to the noticeable imbalance of men to women and children present in this space.

Our focus returns to Preacher, who remains the center of attention. The women observe him with an expression of admiration. He exchanges a meaningful look with Willa as we shift our focus to her, capturing Willa looking both flattered and self-conscious in this moment. Icey enters the scene, whispering something to Willa before beckoning her with a subtle gesture. As the singing continues softly in the background, they both leave the group and start walking towards a shady tree located in the middle ground, which we move to center in our view. As they walk away, with the faint sound of singing still heard in the background, Willa nods in acknowledgment. Icey, looking ahead with intent, shows signs of disapproval subtly etched in her expression. They sit on a bench with their backs turned to us, partially concealed by the trunk of the large tree. They both glance around cautiously, their movements deliberate. As Icey and Willa enter the shot again, their backs are once more to us as they sit on the bench. In the background, the children gradually move towards the river, their youthful energy evident. Willa keeps her head meekly bowed, an air of reflection about her. The singing continues softly, off-screen, adding to the scene's somber mood. Icey pivots, and we pan over to capture the children by the river. John glances up from his pebble-skimming activity, loosens his tie, his brow etched with a thoughtful furrow. He skillfully skims another pebble across the water's surface, watching as it dances over the ripples.

test_cases.name: Macro-Actions -> Micro-Actions
test_cases.description: Reaching down beneath the rocking chair, he retrieves a liquor bottle, holding it momentarily as he prepares to pour its contents. Just before the liquid flows, his attention is caught by a photograph of Bess. The image, encased in a cabinet frame, captures a fine-looking young woman dressed in archaic attire, her sharp, accusing black eyes seeming to pierce through the air. He pauses, then deliberately turns the picture away from his sight before proceeding to pour the liquor into his coffee. They both drink, and John appears cautious as he sips. Birdie's expression shifts, his face falling, and he takes another drink. Setting his cup down with a soft thud, John gets up from his seat and moves towards the door. With deliberate steps, he exits the building and begins to run up the bank, his focus fixed ahead as he resolutely avoids looking back. He continues his brisk pace up the street, nearing Spoon’s, where he abruptly halts, stopping dead in his tracks as a wave of horror washes over him at the sight before him. Through the door-glass from John's perspective, the scene inside unfolds: Preacher, Willa, and Pearl are gathered around a small table, while Walt stands nearby, puffing thoughtfully on his pipe. In the background, Icey is engaged in stirring fudge atop a little soda-fountain stove. Willa appears both moved and pleased, while Pearl shyly flirts with Preacher, nearly disappearing within the folds of Willa's skirts. Preacher, with a practiced ease, bounces Pearl's doll on his knee as he speaks. The adults are all visibly captivated, hanging on to his every word, although these words remain inaudible to John outside. As we shift through the door's barrier, John enters the space quietly and unassumingly. The group acknowledges his presence with casual glances but continues their conversation. John approaches the periphery of the group, his gaze fixated on Preacher's hands and the doll that he playfully holds. Preacher hands the doll back to Pearl, and John's eyes follow its path intently. In a gesture of engagement, Preacher raises both his hands towards John, who returns his gaze to his own hands, remaining still and contemplative. The adults express their approval with a light applause, each impressed in their unique way. Preacher then lifts Pearl, along with her doll, onto his lap, pausing for a moment, his eyes twinkling with a new light as if signaling the onset of a game between them. A quiet tension settles over the room. Icey pours the prepared fudge into a buttered pan, the aroma wafting slightly. The atmosphere is dominated by women and children, with few men present. As we focus on Preacher, the women regard him with admiration. He shares a knowing glance with Willa, prompting us to pan to her, capturing her as she appears wooed yet self-conscious. Icey enters the scene, whispering to Willa and signaling for her to follow, leading them away from the group towards a shade tree. As they walk, the voices of singers in the background accompany them. Willa nods in response to Icey's words, though Icey seems displeased as she gazes ahead. They both settle onto a bench, their backs turned to the viewer and partly obscured by the tree trunk, casting glances around them. Icey and Willa's backs remain facing us, their presence on the bench a quiet, unmoving silhouette. Meanwhile, the children drift towards the river in the distance, their movement a backdrop to the continued singing. John's attention shifts from skillfully skimming pebbles across the water, his brow furrowed in thought, and he adjusts his tie with a reflexive motion. He then resumes his pebble-skimming activity with focused precision.

test_cases.name: Micro-Actions -> Macro-Actions
test_cases.description: He retrieves a liquor bottle from beneath the rocking chair and, pausing to glance at Bess's photograph, a young woman with piercing eyes, he turns her picture away and pours liquor into his coffee. After drinking cautiously alongside Birdie, whose face expresses disappointment, John sets his cup down and leaves. He runs up the bank and the street, stopping in shock near Spoon's, observing through door-glass Preacher, Willa, and Pearl gathered around a table with Walt nearby, smoking his pipe. Icey stirs fudge in the background. Willa appears moved and Pearl flirts shyly with Preacher, who entertains her with her doll. The adults listen intently, and John enters quietly, standing on the fringe as Preacher engages with the group, handing the doll to Pearl. Preacher raises his hands, capturing John's attention, and the adults respond with slight applause. Preacher pulls Pearl onto his lap, engaging in a subtle game with her under tight silence. Icey pours fudge while Preacher commands the admiration of the women, particularly Willa, whom he eyes as Icey whispers to her, leading her towards a shade tree. As they depart, the children drift towards the river, singing continues in the background. John skims pebbles by the river, loosening his tie with a furrowed brow.

test_cases.name: Insert Attributes, Emotions and Scene
test_cases.description: He fetches a liquor bottle from beneath the rocking chair, a sturdy piece of furniture often found in traditional American homes; about to pour, he does a take at Bess's photograph. It stands in a cabinet frame: a fine-looking young woman in archaic dress reminiscent of the early 20th century, with sharp, accusing black eyes. He turns the picture away and splashes aged whiskey into his coffee. They drink. John looks cautious, probably due to the tension in the room. Birdie's face falls; he takes another drink. John puts his cup down and gets up, feeling the weight of the moment. He heads for the door. John runs up the bank, not looking back, perhaps anxious and filled with dread. He runs up the street close to Spoon's, a popular local eatery known for its friendly atmosphere, and stops dead. He is horrified by what he sees. Group shot through door-glass, from John's viewpoint Preacher, known for his charismatic and occasionally intimidating presence, Willa, and Pearl surround a little table. Walt stands by, puffing his pipe, a blend imported from the English countryside. Icey in the background, stirs fudge at a little soda-fountain stove, a nod to the classic sweet shops of the 1950s. Willa looks both moved and pleased. Pearl, shyly flirting with Preacher, all but hides in Willa's skirts. Preacher dandles Pearl's doll on his knee as he talks. All the grownups are avid for his words, which we don't hear through the glass, the tension building as observers strain to know more. We shoot through the door; he quietly enters. They look casually to John and continue talking with an air of forced normality. Over this John enters the shot and stands at the fringe of the group, staring at Preacher's hands and at the doll, an innocent toy symbolizing the power dynamics at play. He hands the doll to Pearl. John's eyes follow the doll. Preacher holds up both hands to John, a gesture of ambiguous meaning. John looks back at his hands. John stands still, a moment heavy with unspoken communication. They are impressed in their different ways. Slight applause from the adults. Preacher takes Pearl, with her doll, onto his lap, creating an image of unsettling intimacy. He does a little take, his eyes twinkle palely, reminiscent of a cunning fox. Something new enters his eyes; a game has begun between them, a psychological chess match. A tight silence. Icey pours fudge into a buttered pan. Few men in proportion to women and children, highlighting the protective presence of Preacher. We center Preacher. The women watch him and admire him, captivated as if under a spell. He gives Willa the eye as we pan to center Willa, who looks wooed and self-conscious. Icey enters the shot and whispers and beckons Willa and, as the singing continues, they leave the group and start towards a shade tree in medium ground, which we pan to center, the tree a silent witness to whispered secrets. They walk; singers in background, their voices blending into the summer breeze. Willa nods. Icey, looking ahead, is displeased, perhaps caught in a web of jealousy or concern. They sit on the bench, their backs to us, partly concealed by the tree trunk. They look around, ensuring privacy in this moment of sharing. Icey and Willa enter the shot, their backs to us. They sit on the bench, their back to us, a pose that speaks of vulnerability. The children recede towards the river in background, a place of freedom and play. Willa meekly keeps her head down. Singing continues o.s. Icey pivots and we pan over her to children by river. John looks up from pebble-skimming and loosens his tie, a relic from an earlier, more formal era. His brow is furrowed, reflecting his inner turmoil. He skims another pebble, his thoughts as unsettled as the ripples he creates.

Under the relentless desert sun a lone gunslinger confronts a notorious outlaw at a deserted crossroads both men exchanging steely glances as swirling dust blurs the horizon. On a foggy evening in Victorian London an intrepid detective uncovers a hidden conspiracy among the city’s elite with gaslit streets setting the stage for a race against a mounting darkness. High above a sprawling city skyline a daredevil pilot executes deathdefying maneuvers in a vintage biplane narrowly evading enemy fire as the ground morphs into a dizzying mosaic below. Within the creaking walls of an old countryside manor an estranged family gathers for a mysterious inheritance their hushed whispers and secret glances weaving a tapestry of betrayal and suspense. Amidst the roaring tempest of a stormy ocean a weathered sailor battles nature’s fury on a creaking vessel his resolve as steadfast as the crashing waves that threaten to engulf him. John looks back at his hands. John stands still. They are impressed in their different ways. Slight applause from the adults. Preacher takes Pearl with her doll onto his lap. He does a little take. His eyes twinkle palely. Something new enters his eyes. a game has begun between them. A tight silence. Icey pours fudge into a buttered pan. Few men in proportion to women and children. We center Preacher. The women watch him and admire him. He gives Willa the eye as we pan to center. Willa who looks wooed and selfconscious. Icey enters the shot and whispers and beckons Willa and as the singing continues they leave the group and start towards a shade tree in medium ground which we pan to center. They walk singers in background. Willa nods. Icey looking ahead is displeased. They sit on the bench their backs to us partly concealed by the tree trunk. They look around. Icey and Willa enter the shot their backs to us. They sit on the bench their back to us. The children recede towards the river in background. Willa meekly keeps her head down. Singing continues os. Icey pivots and we pan over her to children by river. John looks up from pebbleskimming and loosens his tie. His brow is furrowed. He skims another pebble.

test_cases.name: Addition (~80%)
test_cases.description: He fetches a liquor bottle from beneath the rocking chair about to pour. he does a take at Bess's photograph. It stands in a cabinet frame. a finelooking young woman in archaic dress with sharp accusing black eyes. He turns the picture away and splashes liquor into his coffee. They drink. John looks cautious. Birdie's face falls. he takes another drink. John puts his cup down and gets up. He heads for the door. John runs up the bank not looking back. He runs up the street close to Spoon's and stops dead. He is horrified by what he sees. Group shot through doorglass from John's viewpoint. Preacher Willa and Pearl surround a little table. Walt stands by puffing his pipe. Icey in the background stirs fudge at a little sodafountain stove. Willa looks both moved and pleased. Pearl shyly flirting with Preacher all but hides in Willa's skirts. Preacher dandles Pearl's doll on his knee as he talks. All the grownups are avid for his words which we do not hear through the glass. We shoot through the door. he quietly enters. They look casually to John and continue talking. Over this. John enters the shot and stands at the fringe of the group staring at Preacher's hands and at the doll. He hands the doll to Pearl. John's eyes follow the doll. Preacher holds up both hands to John. test_cases.name: Subject-Action-Object Corruption
test_cases.description: She retrieves a paintbrush from under the hammock; about to dip it, she glances at Fred's painting. It hangs in a hallway frame: a striking young boy in ancient armor, with fierce, knowing green eyes. She turns the artwork away and dribbles paint into her tea. They sip. Sarah appears hesitant. Max’s expression drops; he sips further. Sarah places her mug aside and rises. She strides toward the window. Sarah dashes across the meadow, not glancing back. She sprints down the lane near Carlo’s and halts abruptly. She is appalled by what she observes. Group scene through mirror-glass, from Sarah’s angle Baker, Maggie, and Lily encircle a small bench. Hank stands beside, nibbling his cookie. Clara in the distance, mixes cocoa at a tiny picnic stove. Maggie appears both touched and delighted. Lily, bashfully interacting with Baker, nearly hides in Maggie’s shawl. Baker juggles Lily’s puppet on his palm as he speaks. All the adults are keen for his sentences, which we don’t catch through the glass. We capture through the window; she quietly steps inside. They glance nonchalantly at Sarah and continue conversing. Over this Sarah enters the frame and stands at the edge of the gathering, gazing at Baker’s fingers and at the puppet. He passes the puppet to Lily. Sarah’s eyes track the puppet. Baker raises both palms to Sarah. Sarah glances back at his palms. Sarah remains motionless. They are astonished in their varying manners. Gentle clapping from the elders. Baker lifts Lily, with her puppet, onto his knee. He performs a small gesture. His eyes gleam lightly. Something unexpected lights his gaze; a challenge has started between them. A taut hush. Clara spills cocoa into a greased tray. Few women in ratio to men and teenagers. We focus on Baker. The men observe him and praise him. He gives Maggie a nod as we transition to focus on Maggie, who seems charmed and bashful. Clara arrives in the scene and murmurs and gestures to Maggie and, as the song resumes, they depart the group and stroll towards a willow tree in mid-ground, which we shift to focus on. They amble; singers in the backdrop. Maggie agrees. Clara, looking onward, is unsatisfied. They settle on the log, their fronts turned away from us, partly shielded by the tree limb. They peer around. Clara and Maggie enter the scene, their fronts turned away from us. They perch on the log, their fronts turned away from us. The teenagers recede towards the brook in backdrop. Maggie softly keeps her gaze down. Melody continues o.s. Clara pivots and we transition over her to teenagers by brook. Sarah glances up from leaf-tossing and loosens her scarf. Her brow is creased. She tosses another leaf.

test_cases.name: Complete Corruption
test_cases.description: The film starts with a man waking up in a small apartment. He prepares coffee and checks his phone for messages. There are none, so he heads out to catch a bus. On the way, he passes a neighbor who greets him briefly. At the bus stop, he notices a group of students talking about an upcoming test. He boards the bus and sits near the back, watching the city pass by outside the window. After a few stops, he gets off near a large office building. He enters the lobby and goes through security. He rides an elevator to the tenth floor, where he works as an assistant. His manager asks him to prepare some documents for a meeting later in the day. He collects files from different departments and organizes them in a conference room. Another employee asks him for help with a software issue, so he takes a few minutes to fix it. Then he returns to the conference room to double-check everything before the meeting begins. The meeting starts at noon. Several people join via video call, and others sit around the table. The manager outlines the project goals, and each team member shares updates on their tasks. There are questions about deadlines and budgets, but no big surprises. After an hour, they end the call. The manager thanks everyone and leaves. The assistant cleans up the room, collects leftover notes, and heads back to his desk. During lunch, he walks to a nearby café, where he orders a simple meal. He eats alone and checks social media on his phone. After lunch, he returns to the office and finishes smaller tasks, such as sending emails and filing paperwork. He also helps a coworker carry boxes of supplies to another floor. Later in the afternoon, the manager calls him in to discuss next week's schedule. They go over a few changes, and the assistant updates the calendar. When the workday ends, he logs off his computer and leaves the building. Outside, he walks a few blocks to meet a friend. They chat about weekend plans and decide to see a film on Saturday. The assistant then heads home on a crowded bus. At his apartment, he sorts his mail, feeds a pet cat, and warms up leftovers for dinner. He watches a short news segment on TV, then checks his phone again. A message from his friend confirms their plan for the weekend. He feels relieved to have something to look forward to. The film ends with him preparing for bed, setting an alarm, and turning off the lights. He reflects briefly on the day, thinking about his tasks, his quiet home, and the plans ahead.

test_cases.name: Summarization
test_cases.description: John retrieves a liquor bottle from under the chair, hesitates at Bess's accusatory photo, then pours the liquor into his coffee. After drinking cautiously, he sets his cup down and rushes out the door, horrified by a scene through a glass door: Preacher, Willa, and Pearl sit at a table while Walt smokes his pipe and Icey stirs fudge. Pearl shyly interacts with Preacher, who engages the group with captivating words. John enters, observing Preacher's interaction with Pearl's doll. A silent game begins between John and Preacher, and the adults applaud him. Preacher, now holding Pearl and her doll, evokes admiration. Icey whispers to Willa, and they walk to a tree, leaving the group. Willa appears wooed and self-conscious, while Icey seems displeased. As the singing continues, children play by the river. John, deep in thought, skims pebbles, furrowing his brow.
